title: Women are filming themselves dancing to voicemail messages from 'toxic' exes
text:

After a break-up, some of the messages that are sent are quite simply brutal.

If you've ever received a nasty voicemail from an ex, you might not have known how to react initially - do you burst into tears or burst out laughing?

Well a group of women have come up with a very different way to react when you receive this type of message.

They're doing as Taylor Swift said and "shaking off" their haters, by dancing to voicemails on their phones.

The bizarre trend was started by 18-year-old Isabella Dorlando from the US who first shared a clip of herself dancing to a message from her cheating ex-boyfriend on TikTok.

The message says: "I tried all day to talk to you about this but you're just blowing me off. I'm telling you the truth and I'm telling you this, and I don't know what to do. You still don't trust me."

Speaking to Rolling Stone, Isabella revealed that she had been dating the unnamed guy for about six months on and off before they broke up a year ago.

But last week, as she was deleting old messages on her phone, when she came across one from her ex and was struck by how much her feelings for him had changed.

(Image: TikTok)

"It had really bothered me [to hear the message] at the time, but at this point it was just funny."

So she decided to share it on social media and dance along to it, showing she really didn't care about his words anymore.

The video has garnered over 395,000 likes and since posting Isabella has gained around 20,000 new followers.

Moreover, her video has inspired dozens of other women to make their own version.

Tenley Earles from Virginia, thought Isabella's video was "really empowering" and after stumbling across a recording of her ex-boyfriend berating her for wearing leggings to school, she decided to make her own dance clip.

As before, her video went viral, racking up more than 723,000 likes and thousands of comments.

It has also been shared on Twitter , as an example of "toxic masculinity".

Film critic K. Austin Collins shared it, writing: "Your sons are truly out of their f***ing minds, but your daughters are honestly funny as hell."
description: A new trend has cropped up online which sees women creating interpretive dances to voicemail messages from their exes
